issue.title: ipinfo.io gives "Unknown ISP"
issue.body:
## Description
When running the demo service as https://librespeed.org/ , it reports my ISP as unknown.

## Server
https://librespeed.org/

## Client
Firefox, Linux. Chrome, Android.

## Expected behaviour
ipinfo.io should show the correct ISP.

This might be fixed by using https://ifconfig.co/json - although that might also be out of date.

Or by using a free service like https://ipgeolocation.io/pricing.html - although that has 1,000 request limit per day.

Or by using a static database like https://mailfud.org/geoip-legacy/ - although that will need regular updating.

Let me know if you'd like a PR for any of these fixes.

comment.body: The call to IPinfo.io looks OK. Hve you confirmed `getClientIp` is getting the right IP?

issue.title: ipinfo.io gives "Unknown ISP"
issue.body:
## Description
When running the demo service as https://librespeed.org/ , it reports my ISP as unknown.

## Server
https://librespeed.org/

## Client
Firefox, Linux. Chrome, Android.

## Expected behaviour
ipinfo.io should show the correct ISP.

This might be fixed by using https://ifconfig.co/json - although that might also be out of date.

Or by using a free service like https://ipgeolocation.io/pricing.html - although that has 1,000 request limit per day.

Or by using a static database like https://mailfud.org/geoip-legacy/ - although that will need regular updating.

Let me know if you'd like a PR for any of these fixes.

comment.body: The issue doesn't appear to be with our (IPinfo.io)'s data. I also see "Unknown" ISP at https://librespeed.org/ But on https://ipinfo.io I see this So likely the wrong field is being selected, or the request to IPinfo.io is failing, or something similar.

Single file with all metadata makes it harder to add new countries and
changes - because the edit needs to check all attributes instead of just
making the change. I

Id rather have the complexity in well tested loading code that baked into
the schema. Multiple files as simple maps / array seems much better to me
than simpler loading code but complex schema.

Adding new functionality is then a case of adding new simple files, rather
than making a bunch of edits to a single critical file.

And it’s smaller file size too - not a major driver, but a tiny eu.json
will be smaller than a flag on every country, and if we add many more
similar attributes over time it could add up


On Thu, Aug 18 2022 at 8:17 AM, Uman Shahzad ***@***.***>
wrote:

> @coderholic <https://github.com/coderholic> that's a good point we could
> easily make a mistake there on the initial commit, though in future PRs
> it's very easy to see what country is being added/removed from the EU
> because it's 1 country per line now.
>
> One downside with another file is it adds more code, more file loads and
> more variables versus keeping it in that single countries variable and
> not having to load anymore files or really do much else.
>
> One other benefit of this approach is if we have more metadata on
> countries in the future that we want in the SDKs directly, it can all get
> added to this common file. Makes it a lot easier to maintain things
> long-term with a single file (given that we can edit 1 country per line,
> which wasn't the case before).
>
> IIRC this is how we already support currency etc lookups
>
> We don't actually support currency lookups anywhere right now in the SDKs
> or API. If we did support it, it'd need a countryCode -> currencyCode
> mapping for all country codes, which ends up being a duplicate of
> countries.json with only different values.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/ipinfo/python/pull/61#issuecomment-1219481848>, or
> unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAAGLX6IORXWCCS56UIZPT3VZYZW7ANCNFSM564EH6PQ>
> .
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>

See comment here https://github.com/ipinfo/python/pull/61#issuecomment-1219445744

Source file format needs fixing.

Changing countries.json is a bad idea. It makes it more likely to introduce a bug/format error, and makes it harder to update. Instead we shuold have counties.json that has all the country codes to names, and eu.json that's just an array of country codes. If a country joins or leaves the EU we just update that file. IIRC this is how we already support currency etc lookups. Definitel needs refactoring into a separate file before we release this!
